Investment objectives:
The current Queensland Health Finance, Asset and Materials Maintenance Information System (FAMMIS) system is based on a heavily customised solution which is almost 20 years old and no longer supported.
29/8/2018,The objective of the FSR project is to upgrade the existing licences, and transition from FAMMIS to a contemporary solution suite, capable of supporting the Department of Health and all Hospital and Health Services across the state.
29/8/2018,
29/8/2018,The project is proceeding in two stages. The first of which involves the development and evaluation of a solution prototype and the development of a solution roll out plan. The second stage, which is scheduled to commence in the second half of 2017 involves solution configuration and deployment (which will occur in 2018).
29/8/2018,Although there are important ICT components of this project, the major focus is on business-led change management, supported by a skills uplift investment program, to enable the adoption of contemporary best practices across finance, procurement and asset/plant maintenance and to minimise/avoid any system customisation.
29/8/2018,
29/8/2018,As the FSR project proceeds, it will inform the business systems roadmap for Queensland Health, which has a number of other potentially related projects under consideration or development. These include a replacement costing system, a replacement practice management system, consolidation of revenue billing systems, and a new patient administration solution; all of which are intended to contribute to improvements in the management and delivery of health services across the state.

Telehealth is the delivery of health services and information using telecommunication technology. Telehealth can be leveraged to support new and innovative service delivery models in the health sector
29/8/2018,and facilitate access to safe, sustainable and appropriate health care that is simple, equitable and timely for all Queenslanders.
29/8/2018,The Department of Health defines Telehealth as:
29/8/2018,Live, audio and/or video inter-active link for clinical consultations and educational purposes
29/8/2018,Store and forward Telehealth - this model can involve digital images, video, audio and clinical data being captured ("stored") on the client computer; then at a convenient time transmitted securely ("forwarded") to a clinic at another location where they are studied by relevant specialists
29/8/2018,Teleradiology for remote reporting and clinical advice for diagnostic images
29/8/2018,Telehealth services and equipment to monitor peoples health in their home.
29/8/2018,Benefits of Telehealth
29/8/2018,Improve patient access to health care
29/8/2018,Reduce travel and inconvenience for patients, families, carers and health professionals
29/8/2018,Provide health professionals with access to peer support and education.
29/8/2018,The Telehealth Asset Replacement Project is responsible for the replacement of prioritised, highly utilised and critical videoconference systems which have reached their end-of-financial-life.
29/8/2018,The priority is to replace those end-of-life assets which pose the greatest risk to effective health service delivery.

29/8/2018,The GPS Tracking Project is an initial proposal to validate the utility of the technology  prior to seeking a longer term solution.

Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project-generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Initiative name: Government Wireless Network Contract and Administration Billing System
Explanatory notes:
There is a requirement to develop a requirements specification for the GWN Wireless Network Contract and Administration Billing System. This has not been completed as it was determined additional resources were required to progress this project i.e. a Project Manager. Originally this digital project was being resourced by existing staff within the GWN Contract Directorate, therefore no expenditure has occurred to date. The procurement process has been delayed for the same reason, but has recommenced now that a Project Manager has been sourced and commenced employment with the GWN Contract Directorate on Monday 13 August.
29/8/2018,
Investment objectives:
The GWN Contract Directorate seeks a fully managed software as a service solution to replace existing excel spreadsheets and macros that have organically grown in complexity, improve record keeping compliance, and alleviate current single points of failure and reliance. 
29/8/2018,The current contract modification process and Public Safety Agencies (GWN service consumers) invoicing is managed via complicated spreadsheets and macros, colloquially called The Mod Register. The management of contract modifications and invoicing via the Mod Register is manually intensive, cumbersome, is pushing the capabilities of Microsoft Excel, prone to macro errors and due to its size is becoming unwieldly to manage. Also,
29/8/2018,Contractor Performance, including the contractor abatement calculation process, is not centrally managed in one system. A variety of Contractor generated reports are manually validated and reconciled, with problematic auditability.
29/8/2018,Communication of information between GWN Contract Directorate, Public Safety Agencies and Contractor is done via email and attachments of spreadsheets and PDFs in these emails. Management and storage of emails and attachments is problematic, especially version history and control.
29/8/2018,There is now a requirement to procure a purposely designed software system that is fully functional, customisable, redundant, reliable, will meet the current and future requirements of the GWN Contract, and replace current Contract Modification and Contractor Performance processes.

Explanatory notes: July 2017:  Project reported for first time.

19/12/2017,
19/12/2017,Once implemented, EPMA will facilitate the electronic generation of prescriptions; transfer of the order to pharmacy and medication supply systems; then facilitate and record the administration of medication to inpatients in Metro North Hospital and Health Service (MNHHS).  
19/12/2017,
19/12/2017,The Stage 1 project involves implementing an information communication technology (ICT) solution in two sites in MNHHS in order to investigate the costs and benefits of such an approach.  Stage 2 will deliver EPMA capability (with one or more vendor options) into further clinical settings and Stage 3 will implement EPMA across all services and facilities in MNHHS.  
19/12/2017,
19/12/2017,Anticipated benefits include: improved patient health outcomes through medication safety and enhance "quality use of medicines"; staff enabled and supported in medication prescribing and administration decisions and processes; increased compliance with medication-related legal, policy and audit requirements; reduced risk (legal, financial, patient safety); improved revenue generation opportunities with PBS script generation; reduction in medication-related harm and incidents; and delivery on health service strategic intent.

The overall goal of the Integrated Mental Health Data Reporting Repository (IMHDRR) is to create a central mental health reporting repository that collates data from multiple source systems and provides the mechanisms to report comprehensive information about mental health consumers and services. 
19/12/2017,The ongoing program of work aims to continue and build upon existing functionality by: 
19/12/2017,(a) Including additional data from current source systems, including data related to the Mental Health Act 2016 and clinical outcome measurement 
19/12/2017,(b) Integrating new data sources (such as the Mental Health Establishments Collection and Emergency Department Collection) 
19/12/2017,(c) Creating a 'self-service' functionality that will support HHS to improve the basis of planning and decision making through flexible and tailored analysis and reporting. This is a key initiative within Priority 3 of Connecting Care to Recovery 2016-2021 
19/12/2017,(d) Supporting access to a broader range of Queensland Health stakeholders to timely and quality mental health data and analysis. 
19/12/2017,(e) Supporting utilisation of clinical quality information by HHS and the Department of Health.

Project Purpose:
19/12/2017,Queensland Health is driving a huge eHealth Strategy to keep pace with the increasing demand for digital health services, to shift towards a customer-centric health system, and to enable cutting edge health service delivery.
19/12/2017,Central to the eHealth strategy is addressing issues related to ageing systems, in particular addressing the risk to health service delivery, and removing barriers to contemporary practice.
19/12/2017,Currently, eHealth Queensland is hosting a number of mission critical applications on the ageing application server platform. While this platform has provided a robust and highly available environment, it is now seven years old with increased risks to reliability and serviceability, has limited options for expansion, and is unable to provide the agile foundation required for advancing the eHealth Strategy. As such, it is an appropriate time to investigate replacement of the platform.
19/12/2017,This project aims to establish a robust, highly available and secure contemporary platform that has the 
19/12/2017,93Scale Out
19/12/2017,94 capability to support the agile eHealth Strategy.

The scope of the SBAR project is the preliminary evaluation and requirements specification for the SAR and Backup Asset Replacement (BAR) projects.
19/12/2017,The SAR project seeks to outline architecture for storage that will provide a cost effective, scalable and fit for purpose environment for the future of storage services within Queensland Health.
19/12/2017,a0 Utilising space saving technologies which will enable further cost savings and reduce the requirement for capacity expansion in the short to medium term.

19/12/2017,a0 These storage arrays are at capacity and will be at the end of extended vendor support in May 2018.

Project Purpose:
19/12/2017,a0
19/12/2017,a0
19/12/2017,Telehealth is the delivery of health services and information using telecommunication technology. Telehealth can be leveraged to support new and innovative service delivery models in the health sector
19/12/2017,a0
19/12/2017,and facilitate access to safe, sustainable and appropriate health care that is simple, equitable and timely for all Queenslanders.
19/12/2017,The Department of Health defines Telehealth as:
19/12/2017,(a) Live, audio and/or video inter-active link for clinical consultations and educational purposes
19/12/2017,(b) Store and forward Telehealth - this model can involve digital images, video, audio and clinical data being captured ("stored") on the client computer; then at a convenient time transmitted securely ("forwarded")
19/12/2017,a0 to a clinic at another location where they are studied by relevant specialists
19/12/2017,(c) Teleradiology for remote reporting and clinical advice for diagnostic images
19/12/2017,(d) Telehealth services and equipment to monitor people
19/12/2017,92s health in their home.
19/12/2017,Benefits of Telehealth
19/12/2017,(a) Improve patient access to health care
19/12/2017,(b) Reduce travel and inconvenience for patients, families, carers and health professionals
19/12/2017,(c) Provide health professionals with access to peer support and education.
19/12/2017,The Telehealth Asset Replacement Project is responsible for the replacement of prioritised, highly utilised and critical videoconference systems which have reached their end-of-financial-life.
19/12/2017,a0
19/12/2017,The priority is to replace those end-of-life assets which pose the greatest risk to effective health service delivery.
19/12/2017,Each year the project will prioritise and maintain the replacement scope in the Prioritised Operations List based on the risk impact assessment for each in-scope asset to establish a most-to-least critical replacement ranking.

Explanatory notes: Online National Police Certificate successfully launched on the Queensland Police website on the 13th of November 2017.
Investment objectives: The Online National Police Certificate Project will implement an online service for the community to apply and pay for Name Only National Police Certificates online, rather than presenting at a police station, or using the online services of an Australian Crime Intelligence Commission accredited broker. This will provide improved customer service to the community through a more efficient and reliable QPS service, with no requirement to present at a police station, as well as provide efficiency and time savings to local police stations and the Police Information Centre.

Initiative name: Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project
Explanatory notes: Partial funding for the Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project has been approved and included in the 2017-18 budget. The Invitation to Offer process has commenced and negotiation is currently being conducted with vendors to finalise the price and delivery time-frames. Additional funding is currently being sought through the QPS budget process.
Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project-generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Explanatory notes: The project continues to deliver new capability in all streams with most capability available for use as business-as-usual during the 2018 Commonwealth Games. Current focus is on expanding the capability developed by the project in 2017-18 and the development of the business case for the next phase of QPS advanced data analytics capabilities.
Investment objectives: Develop the QPS Advanced Data Analytics proof-of-concept. This proof-of-concept is intended to inform a larger suite of data analytics integration and intelligence over the next four years, including the development of predictive and alert models to enhance the operational response to threats, incidents and events.

Explanatory notes: The Program will complete the deployment of all Stage Two body worn cameras by December 2017 and will then complete transition and closure activities by 30 June 2018. A Business Case for additional funding for a Stage Three rollout in 2018-19 has been prepared for Government consideration.  A successful Stage Three rollout would see body worn cameras provided to every frontline operational police officer in Queensland.
Investment objectives: The Queensland Police Service Body Worn Camera Project is deploying 5100 body worn cameras to frontline police officers. Body worn cameras will be deployed to 168 police stations, 16 tactical crime units, 47 road policing units, and specialist units including dog squads and the Public Safety Response Team in two stages. The cameras integrate with the QPS mobility devices, allowing officers to add metadata to videos and to review videos in the field. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

This project will improve and integrate the external and internal applications and reduce duplicated processes for high-risk work licensing stakeholders whilst meeting legislative requirements.  One simplified online service will be delivered for assessors that will save them time and make compliance easier.

Initiative name: Blue Card Services Recommendation 28.1 Project - Blue Card Home Based Care Register
Explanatory notes:
In July 2016, the Queensland Family and Child Commission QFCC released the When a child is missing Remembering Tiahleigh - A report into Queensland's children missing from out-of-home care report making 29 recommendations. Recommendation 28 required the QFCC to undertake a further review of legislation, policies and practices relating to information sharing between relevant agencies responsible for children in regulated service environments. 
30/12/2018,The Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review, A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home based services (Supplementary Review) is the QFCC response to Recommendation 28 and makes 17 recommendations in relation to information sharing between agencies responsible for regulating and monitoring regulated services provided from the home, namely foster and kinship care, family day care and stand alone care services. 
30/12/2018,Implementation of the register will require legislative amendment.
Investment objectives:
The objective of this project is to establish a register for recording and reporting on regulated child-related services provided from the home, specifically limited to foster/kinship care, family day care and stand-alone care. As recommended by the Queensland Family and Child Commission (QFCC) within the Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review Report (A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home-based services) this register will: 
30/12/2018,a) identify co-located home-based services
30/12/2018,b) enable the Queensland Police Service to have line of sight to the register to access up-to-date information when Police attend a residential address to identify potential risks to children, and 
30/12/2018,c) make information available to agencies, including Department of Child Safety, Youth and Women, Department of Education and the Office of the Public Guardian to assist with regulating and/or monitoring specific home-based services.

Initiative name: Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project
Explanatory notes: Previous Invitation to Offer considered and not proceeded with as it was deemed financially un-viable. Project asked to re-scope the market and conduct new Invitation to Offer to establish if vendors for a more affordable and innovative solution are available. Meeting with relevant stakeholders to be organised to discuss way forward.
Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project-generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Body worn cameras will be deployed to 168 police stations, 16 tactical crime units, 47 road policing units, and specialist units including dog squads and the Public Safety Response Team in two stages. The cameras integrate with the QPS mobility devices, allowing officers to add metadata to videos and to review videos in the field. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

23/1/2018,The existing storage arrays at Cairns, Townsville and Gold Coast are classed as urgent and unavoidable asset replacements.
23/1/2018,a0 These storage arrays are at capacity and will be at the end of extended vendor support in May 2018.

Initiative name: Child and Family Services Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Program
Explanatory notes: Original planned expenditure represented approved budget from start date to 30 June 2016. This program is a multi year program and the revised total expenditure has been updated to include  approved funding to 30 June 2018.
Investment objectives: This five year program will investigate, provide options and implement ICT solutions to enable Child Safety in addressing recommendations of the Queensland Child Protection Commission of Inquiry. This may include enhancements to current systems, consideration of new systems and enabling activities to address changes to policy, legislation and practice reforms resulting from the outcomes of the Inquiry.

Investment objectives: This project will deliver an integrated streamlined solution to support the department in the management of disasters.

Explanatory notes: Online National Police Certificate successfully launched on the Queensland Police website on the 13th of November 2017.
Investment objectives: The Online National Police Certificate Project will implement an online service for the community to apply and pay for Name Only National Police Certificates online, rather than presenting at a police station, or using the online services of an Australian Crime Intelligence Commission accredited broker. This will provide improved customer service to the community through a more efficient and reliable QPS service, with no requirement to present at a police station, as well as provide efficiency and time savings to local police stations and the Police Information Centre.

Initiative name: Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project
Explanatory notes: Partial funding for the Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project has been approved and included in the 2017-18 budget. The Invitation to Offer process has commenced and negotiation is currently being conducted with vendors to finalise the price and delivery time-frames. Additional funding is currently being sought through the QPS budget process.
Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project-generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Explanatory notes: The project continues to deliver new capability in all streams with most capability available for use as business-as-usual during the 2018 Commonwealth Games. Current focus is on expanding the capability developed by the project in 2017-18 and the development of the business case for the next phase of QPS advanced data analytics capabilities.
Investment objectives: Develop the QPS Advanced Data Analytics proof-of-concept. This proof-of-concept is intended to inform a larger suite of data analytics integration and intelligence over the next four years, including the development of predictive and alert models to enhance the operational response to threats, incidents and events.

Explanatory notes: The Program will complete the deployment of all Stage Two body worn cameras by December 2017 and will then complete transition and closure activities by 30 June 2018. A Business Case for additional funding for a Stage Three rollout in 2018-19 has been prepared for Government consideration.  A successful Stage Three rollout would see body worn cameras provided to every frontline operational police officer in Queensland.
Investment objectives: The Queensland Police Service Body Worn Camera Project is deploying 5100 body worn cameras to frontline police officers. Body worn cameras will be deployed to 168 police stations, 16 tactical crime units, 47 road policing units, and specialist units including dog squads and the Public Safety Response Team in two stages. The cameras integrate with the QPS mobility devices, allowing officers to add metadata to videos and to review videos in the field. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

This project will improve and integrate the external and internal applications and reduce duplicated processes for high-risk work licensing stakeholders whilst meeting legislative requirements.  One simplified online service will be delivered for assessors that will save them time and make compliance easier.

Initiative name: Blue Card Services Recommendation 28.1 Project - Blue Card Home Based Care Register
Explanatory notes:
In July 2016, the Queensland Family and Child Commission QFCC released the When a child is missing Remembering Tiahleigh - A report into Queensland's children missing from out-of-home care report making 29 recommendations. Recommendation 28 required the QFCC to undertake a further review of legislation, policies and practices relating to information sharing between relevant agencies responsible for children in regulated service environments. 
21/1/2019,The Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review, A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home based services (Supplementary Review) is the QFCC response to Recommendation 28 and makes 17 recommendations in relation to information sharing between agencies responsible for regulating and monitoring regulated services provided from the home, namely foster and kinship care, family day care and stand alone care services. 
21/1/2019,Implementation of the register will require legislative amendment.
Investment objectives:
The objective of this project is to establish a register for recording and reporting on regulated child-related services provided from the home, specifically limited to foster/kinship care, family day care and stand-alone care. As recommended by the Queensland Family and Child Commission (QFCC) within the Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review Report (A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home-based services) this register will: 
21/1/2019,a) identify co-located home-based services
21/1/2019,b) enable the Queensland Police Service to have line of sight to the register to access up-to-date information when Police attend a residential address to identify potential risks to children, and 
21/1/2019,c) make information available to agencies, including Department of Child Safety, Youth and Women, Department of Education and the Office of the Public Guardian to assist with regulating and/or monitoring specific home-based services.

24/7/2018,Although there are important ICT components of this project, the major focus is on business-led change management, supported by a skills uplift investment program, to enable the adoption of contemporary best practices across finance, procurement and asset/plant maintenance and to minimise/avoid any system customisation.

Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

Initiative name: Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project
Explanatory notes: Previous Invitation to Offer considered and not proceeded with as it was deemed financially un-viable. Project asked to re-scope the market and conduct new Invitation to Offer to establish if vendors for a more affordable and innovative solution are available. Meeting with relevant stakeholders to be organised to discuss way forward.
Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project-generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Body worn cameras will be deployed to 168 police stations, 16 tactical crime units, 47 road policing units, and specialist units including dog squads and the Public Safety Response Team in two stages. The cameras integrate with the QPS mobility devices, allowing officers to add metadata to videos and to review videos in the field. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

Project Purpose:
24/11/2017,a0
24/11/2017,a0
24/11/2017,Telehealth is the delivery of health services and information using telecommunication technology. Telehealth can be leveraged to support new and innovative service delivery models in the health sector
24/11/2017,a0
24/11/2017,and facilitate access to safe, sustainable and appropriate health care that is simple, equitable and timely for all Queenslanders.
24/11/2017,The Department of Health defines Telehealth as:
24/11/2017,(a) Live, audio and/or video inter-active link for clinical consultations and educational purposes
24/11/2017,(b) Store and forward Telehealth - this model can involve digital images, video, audio and clinical data being captured ("stored") on the client computer; then at a convenient time transmitted securely ("forwarded")
24/11/2017,a0 to a clinic at another location where they are studied by relevant specialists
24/11/2017,(c) Teleradiology for remote reporting and clinical advice for diagnostic images
24/11/2017,(d) Telehealth services and equipment to monitor people
24/11/2017,92s health in their home.
24/11/2017,Benefits of Telehealth
24/11/2017,(a) Improve patient access to health care
24/11/2017,(b) Reduce travel and inconvenience for patients, families, carers and health professionals
24/11/2017,(c) Provide health professionals with access to peer support and education.
24/11/2017,The Telehealth Asset Replacement Project is responsible for the replacement of prioritised, highly utilised and critical videoconference systems which have reached their end-of-financial-life.
24/11/2017,a0
24/11/2017,The priority is to replace those end-of-life assets which pose the greatest risk to effective health service delivery.
24/11/2017,Each year the project will prioritise and maintain the replacement scope in the Prioritised Operations List based on the risk impact assessment for each in-scope asset to establish a most-to-least critical replacement ranking.

Investment objectives: The Online National Police Certificate Project will implement an online service for the community to apply and pay for Name Only National Police Certificates online, rather than presenting at a police station, or using the online services of an Australian Crime Intelligence Commission accredited broker. This will provide improved customer service to the community through a more efficient and reliable QPS service, with no requirement to present at a police station, as well as provide efficiency and time savings to local police stations and the Police Information Centre.

Explanatory notes: Funding for the Police Integrity and Professional Standards  Project has been approved and included in the 2017-18 budget. The Invitation to Offer Process has commenced.
Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Explanatory notes: The Program will complete the deployment of all Stage Two body worn cameras by December 2017 and will then complete transition and closure activities by 30 June 2018. A Business Case for additional funding for a Stage Three rollout in 2018-19 has been prepared for Government consideration.  A successful Stage Three rollout would see body worn cameras provided to every frontline operational police officer in Queensland.
Investment objectives: The Queensland Police Service Body Worn Camera Project is deploying 5100 body worn cameras to frontline police officers. Body worn cameras will be deployed to 168 police stations, 16 tactical crime units, 47 road policing units, and specialist units including dog squads and the Public Safety Response Team in two stages. The cameras integrate with the QPS mobility devices, allowing officers to add metadata to videos and to review videos in the field. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

Investment objectives: The RAPS Assessor Portal project commenced as an initiative to target improving services for high risk work licensing accredited assessors, registered training organisations and licensing and advisory services. Currently accredited assessors must use a combination of cumbersome paper based processes, smart forms, and an online service that is difficult to use.  This project will improve and integrate the external and internal applications and reduce duplicated processes for high-risk work licensing stakeholders whilst meeting legislative requirements.  One simplified online service will be delivered for assessors that will save them time and make compliance easier.

Investment objectives: Cabinet has approved the reform of the Financial Assurance System in Queensland to address the inadequacy of surety held by the state to meets its rehabilitation obligations relating to mining and petroleum sites and activities.  The Financial Assurance Information Registry (FAIR) will provide a robust and accurate central registry of information pertaining to Financial Assurance relating to mining interests in Queensland.  The registry will be accessible to Queensland Government officers in Dept. of Environment and Heritage Protection, Dept. of Natural Resources and Mines and Queensland Treasury.

Initiative name: Blue Card Services Recommendation 28.1 Project - Blue Card Home Based Care Register
Explanatory notes:
In July 2016, the Queensland Family and Child Commission QFCC released the When a child is missing Remembering Tiahleigh - A report into Queensland's children missing from out-of-home care report making 29 recommendations. Recommendation 28 required the QFCC to undertake a further review of legislation, policies and practices relating to information sharing between relevant agencies responsible for children in regulated service environments. 
22/11/2018,The Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review, A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home based services (Supplementary Review) is the QFCC response to Recommendation 28 and makes 17 recommendations in relation to information sharing between agencies responsible for regulating and monitoring regulated services provided from the home, namely foster and kinship care, family day care and stand alone care services. 
22/11/2018,Implementation of the register will require legislative amendment.
Investment objectives:
The objective of this project is to establish a register for recording and reporting on regulated child-related services provided from the home, specifically limited to foster/kinship care, family day care and stand-alone care. As recommended by the Queensland Family and Child Commission (QFCC) within the Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review Report (A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home-based services) this register will: 
22/11/2018,a) identify co-located home-based services
22/11/2018,b) enable the Queensland Police Service to have line of sight to the register to access up-to-date information when Police attend a residential address to identify potential risks to children, and 
22/11/2018,c) make information available to agencies, including Department of Child Safety, Youth and Women, Department of Education and the Office of the Public Guardian to assist with regulating and/or monitoring specific home-based services.

The registry will be accessible to Queensland Government officers in Dept. of Environment and Heritage Protection, Dept. of Natural Resources and Mines and Queensland Treasury.

23/10/2018,

This vision of integrated care processes is enabled through seamless access, at the point of care, to necessary health information and efficient transactional capabilities that support the care continuum.

Initiative name: Queensland Health Integrated Processing System establishment (QHIDSe)
Explanatory notes: May: This project has been reported for the first time.
Investment objectives: The QHIDSe project will develop in-house the foundation of an integrated processing system (i.e. QHIDS (Queensland Health Integrated Data System) using agile techniques and software development tools enabling QHIDS to be used as a replacement for the Queensland Hospital Inpatient Processing System (QHIPS, which processes the Queensland Hospital Admitted Patient Data Collection) and extended through future initiatives to provide new functionality.

Explanatory notes: June: This project has been reported for the first time.
Investment objectives: The vector surveillance and control program requires a state-wide surveillance and control solution to assist with the response to the risk of Dengue, Zika and Chikungunya virus outbreaks in vulnerable North Queensland and the mitigation of emerging risks across Central and Southern Queensland.

Explanatory notes: July: This project has commenced reporting for the first time.
Investment objectives: Telehealth is the delivery of health services and information using telecommunication technology. Telehealth can be leveraged to support new and innovative service delivery models in the health sector and facilitate access to safe, sustainable and appropriate health care that is simple, equitable and timely for all Queenslanders. The Telehealth Asset Replacement Project is responsible for the replacement of prioritised, highly utilised and critical videoconference systems which have reached their end-of-financial-life.

Explanatory notes: July: This project has commenced reporting for the first time.
Investment objectives: The Connecting Care Information Program - CCI -will support streamlining and improvement of clinical and administrative workflows through delivery of key Information Technology (IT) enablers.

Initiative name: Metro North Health and Hospital Service Contemporary Workspace Phase 1
Explanatory notes: July: This project has commenced reporting for the first time.

Additionally, the solution seeks to provide greater flexibility in the provision of outpatient services, allowing patients to better manage their care.

Investment objectives: This project will deliver a state-wide capability for referrers to lodge patient referrals electronically with Queensland Health. The referral will be automatically routed to the appropriate Hospital and Health Service (HHS).

The Infrastructure Capacity Project is responsible for managing capacity requests across the organisation to improve the level of service and accessibility of data across Queensland Health. The project is based on the identified organic growth requirements to replace/upgrade ICT infrastructure or expanding ICT assets to allow services to continue functioning. ICT assets include storage capacity, network switches, wireless and software licensing, etc.
The Server Asset Replacement Project is responsible for replacing prioritised, highly utilised and critical server assets which are coming to, or have reached, end-of-financial-life.

To replace the current versions of the Digital Dictation Systems in use at MNHHS facilities with the newest release of the product. The new release introduces efficiencies in the workflow process and contributes to patient care improvement through reduction in timeframe to complete patient letters.

Explanatory notes:
Legislation provisioning for GPS monitoring of court bailed offenders commenced on 31/3/18.  QPS established interim GPS tracking capability leveraging existing contract held by Queensland Corrective Services.
23/10/2018,QPS is now undertaking a Whole of Government open Invitation-to-Offer to establish a longer term contract for GPS tracking devices and monitoring of offenders.
23/10/2018,Note: The project is currently undergoing procurement/commercial activity and is therefore not publishing any financial data.
Investment objectives:
As per the Commencement of the Bail (Domestic Violence) and Another Act Amendment Act 2017 (the Amending Act) on 30 March 2018, Magistrates will be empowered to impose a tracking condition on a defendant granted bail as a condition of their bail undertaking. 
23/10/2018,As such the QPS intends to progressively implement an electronic monitoring capability on a State Wide basis.
23/10/2018,An implementation project has commenced to create an electronic monitoring capability for geographically locating and monitoring a defendant on bail for QPS to meet requirements of the Amended Act.
23/10/2018,The GPS Tracking Project is an initial proposal to validate the utility of the technology  prior to seeking a longer term solution.

Explanatory notes:
Since the successful launch of Online National Police Certificates 83% of all applications have been submitted online.  The project is now officially closed effective 31 July 2018 and has transitioned to business as usual.
23/10/2018, 
23/10/2018,Feb 18: The revised project budget has been amended from previously published figures to reflect the increased investment in promotional products.
Investment objectives: The Online National Police Certificate Project will implement an online service for the community to apply and pay for Name Only National Police Certificates online, rather than presenting at a police station, or using the online services of an Australian Crime Intelligence Commission accredited broker. This will provide improved customer service to the community through a more efficient and reliable QPS service, with no requirement to present at a police station, as well as provide efficiency and time savings to local police stations and the Police Information Centre.

Explanatory notes:
Full funding has now been approved for the Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT system. 
23/10/2018,
23/10/2018,The Project has received a green assessment for the Gate 3 Quality Assurance Review and will commence delivery in July 2018 with an approved revised project end date of 31 December 2019.  
23/10/2018,
23/10/2018,Feb 18: Note: original planned end date amended as previously published information was incorrect.
Investment objectives: This initiative will deliver a new integrated Police Integrity and Professional Standards IT System replacing multiple existing systems across the suite of business activities undertaken within the Ethical Standards Command. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will provide advanced reporting and analytics, as well as improve current business processes, in particular around the management of complaints. The Police Integrity and Professional Standards Project will also complement the Complaints Reform Project established by the QPS to deliver process reform addressing deficiencies in its complaints and discipline systems. Implementation of the Police Integrity and Professional Standards system will place the QPS in a strong readiness position to fully implement Complaints Reform Project-generated changes to disciplinary processes and immediately deliver the benefits of these changes.

Explanatory notes:
The Project completed the deployment of all Stage Two body worn cameras in December 2017 and transitioned to business as usual on 30 June 2018.  The Project is now going through approval for formal closure.
23/10/2018,
23/10/2018,Feb 2018: The original budget was $6.03M.  In May 2017, the QPS Demand and Resource Committee approved an additional $0.860M, making the total approved budget $6.890M
Investment objectives: The Queensland Police Service Body Worn Camera Project is deploying 5100 body worn cameras to frontline police officers. Body worn cameras will be deployed to 168 police stations, 16 tactical crime units, 47 road policing units, and specialist units including dog squads and the Public Safety Response Team in two stages. The cameras integrate with the QPS mobility devices, allowing officers to add metadata to videos and to review videos in the field. A system for storage and allocation of digital camera data will also be implemented as well as policy related to use of the cameras.

Initiative name: Blue Card Services Recommendation 28.1 Project - Blue Card Home Based Care Register
Explanatory notes:
In July 2016, the Queensland Family and Child Commission QFCC released the When a child is missing Remembering Tiahleigh - A report into Queensland's children missing from out-of-home care report making 29 recommendations. Recommendation 28 required the QFCC to undertake a further review of legislation, policies and practices relating to information sharing between relevant agencies responsible for children in regulated service environments. 
23/10/2018,The Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review, A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home based services (Supplementary Review) is the QFCC response to Recommendation 28 and makes 17 recommendations in relation to information sharing between agencies responsible for regulating and monitoring regulated services provided from the home, namely foster and kinship care, family day care and stand alone care services. 
23/10/2018,Implementation of the register will require legislative amendment.
Investment objectives:
The objective of this project is to establish a register for recording and reporting on regulated child-related services provided from the home, specifically limited to foster/kinship care, family day care and stand-alone care. As recommended by the Queensland Family and Child Commission (QFCC) within the Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review Report (A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home-based services) this register will: 
23/10/2018,a) identify co-located home-based services
23/10/2018,b) enable the Queensland Police Service to have line of sight to the register to access up-to-date information when Police attend a residential address to identify potential risks to children, and 
23/10/2018,c) make information available to agencies, including Department of Child Safety, Youth and Women, Department of Education and the Office of the Public Guardian to assist with regulating and/or monitoring specific home-based services.

Initiative name: Government Wireless Network Contract and Administration Billing System
Explanatory notes:
There is a requirement to develop a requirements specification for the GWN Wireless Network Contract and Administration Billing System. This has not been completed as it was determined additional resources were required to progress this project i.e. a Project Manager. Originally this digital project was being resourced by existing staff within the GWN Contract Directorate, therefore no expenditure has occurred to date. The procurement process has been delayed for the same reason, but has recommenced now that a Project Manager has been sourced and commenced employment with the GWN Contract Directorate on Monday 13 August.
23/10/2018,
Investment objectives:
The GWN Contract Directorate seeks a fully managed software as a service solution to replace existing excel spreadsheets and macros that have organically grown in complexity, improve record keeping compliance, and alleviate current single points of failure and reliance. 
23/10/2018,The current contract modification process and Public Safety Agencies (GWN service consumers) invoicing is managed via complicated spreadsheets and macros, colloquially called The Mod Register. The management of contract modifications and invoicing via the Mod Register is manually intensive, cumbersome, is pushing the capabilities of Microsoft Excel, prone to macro errors and due to its size is becoming unwieldly to manage. Also,
23/10/2018,Contractor Performance, including the contractor abatement calculation process, is not centrally managed in one system. A variety of Contractor generated reports are manually validated and reconciled, with problematic auditability.
23/10/2018,Communication of information between GWN Contract Directorate, Public Safety Agencies and Contractor is done via email and attachments of spreadsheets and PDFs in these emails. Management and storage of emails and attachments is problematic, especially version history and control.
23/10/2018,There is now a requirement to procure a purposely designed software system that is fully functional, customisable, redundant, reliable, will meet the current and future requirements of the GWN Contract, and replace current Contract Modification and Contractor Performance processes.

Initiative name: Blue Card Services Recommendation 28.1 Project - Blue Card Home Based Care Register
Explanatory notes:
In July 2016, the Queensland Family and Child Commission QFCC released the When a child is missing Remembering Tialeigh, A report into Queenslands children missing from out of home care report making 29 recommendations. Recommendation 28 required the QFCC to undertake a further review of legislation, policies and practices relating to information sharing between relevant agencies responsible for children in regulated service environments. 
20/9/2018,The Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review, A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home based services (Supplementary Review) is the QFCC response to Recommendation 28 and makes 17 recommendations in relation to information sharing between agencies responsible for regulating and monitoring regulated services provided from the home, namely foster and kinship care, family day care and stand alone care services. 
20/9/2018,Implementation of the register will require legislative amendment.
Investment objectives:
The objective of this project is to establish a register for recording and reporting on regulated child-related services provided from the home, specifically limited to foster/kinship care, family day care and stand-alone care. As recommended by the Queensland Family and Child Commission (QFCC) within the Recommendation 28 Supplementary Review Report (A report on information sharing to enhance the safety of children in regulated home-based services) this register will: 
20/9/2018,a) identify co-located home-based services
20/9/2018,b) enable the Queensland Police Service to have line of sight to the register to access up-to-date information when Police attend a residential address to identify potential risks to children, and 
20/9/2018,c) make information available to agencies, including Department of Child Safety, Youth and Women, Department of Education and the Office of the Public Guardian to assist with regulating and/or monitoring specific home-based services.

Initiative name: Government Wireless Network Contract and Administration Billing System
Explanatory notes:
There is a requirement to develop a requirements specification for the GWN Wireless Network Contract and Administration Billing System. This has not been completed as it was determined additional resources were required to progress this project i.e. a Project Manager. Originally this digital project was being resourced by existing staff within the GWN Contract Directorate, therefore no expenditure has occurred to date. The procurement process has been delayed for the same reason, but has recommenced now that a Project Manager has been sourced and commenced employment with the GWN Contract Directorate on Monday 13 August.
20/9/2018,
Investment objectives:
The GWN Contract Directorate seeks a fully managed software as a service solution to replace existing excel spreadsheets and macros that have organically grown in complexity, improve record keeping compliance, and alleviate current single points of failure and reliance. 
20/9/2018,The current contract modification process and Public Safety Agencies (GWN service consumers) invoicing is managed via complicated spreadsheets and macros, colloquially called The Mod Register. The management of contract modifications and invoicing via the Mod Register is manually intensive, cumbersome, is pushing the capabilities of Microsoft Excel, prone to macro errors and due to its size is becoming unwieldly to manage. Also,
20/9/2018,Contractor Performance, including the contractor abatement calculation process, is not centrally managed in one system. A variety of Contractor generated reports are manually validated and reconciled, with problematic auditability.
20/9/2018,Communication of information between GWN Contract Directorate, Public Safety Agencies and Contractor is done via email and attachments of spreadsheets and PDFs in these emails. Management and storage of emails and attachments is problematic, especially version history and control.
20/9/2018,There is now a requirement to procure a purposely designed software system that is fully functional, customisable, redundant, reliable, will meet the current and future requirements of the GWN Contract, and replace current Contract Modification and Contractor Performance processes.

Explanatory notes:

20/9/2018,
